title: As a user, I want the Dockerfile to run brew as a non-root user

labels.name: outdated
labels.description: PR was locked due to age

body:
### `brew config` output

```shell
➜ docker run --rm homebrew/brew:3.2.5 brew config
Error: Running Homebrew as root is extremely dangerous and no longer supported.
As Homebrew does not drop privileges on installation you would be giving all
build scripts full access to your system.
```


### `brew doctor` output

```shell
➜ docker run --rm homebrew/brew:3.2.5 brew doctor
Error: Running Homebrew as root is extremely dangerous and no longer supported.
As Homebrew does not drop privileges on installation you would be giving all
build scripts full access to your system.
```


### 

- [X] I ran `brew update` and am still able to reproduce my issue.
- [X] I have resolved all warnings from `brew doctor` and that did not fix my problem.

### What were you trying to do (and why)?

I'm currently working to add a new package, and am attempting to run `brew` via Docker to avoid installing it directly on my system -- because I do not install packages via shell scripts (only through my system package manager), and there is not a currently available package for my particular Linux distribution.

### What happened (include all command output)?

Running any command at all results in the following error:

```
➜ docker run --rm homebrew/brew:latest brew help
Error: Running Homebrew as root is extremely dangerous and no longer supported.
As Homebrew does not drop privileges on installation you would be giving all
build scripts full access to your system.
```

### What did you expect to happen?

I would expect the docker image to invoke the `brew` executable without issue.

### Step-by-step reproduction instructions (by running `brew` commands)

```shell
$ docker pull homebrew/brew:3.2.5
$ docker run --rm homebrew/brew brew <any subcommand>
```

**Note that the `3.2.5` tag is currently mapped to the same digest as `latest`.**
